4.text:
Dr Nicholas Cullinan:– Good morning everyone
and thank you so much for being here. I'm

7.text:
Nicholas Cullinan, Director of the National
Portrait Gallery and I am thrilled to welcome

11.text:
you to the ninth Understanding British Portraits
Annual Seminar. I just want to give a bit

17.text:
of the general context around the Annual Seminar
for those of you who are new to the network

21.text:
and that includes me. So, this is the flagship
event in the Understanding British Portraits

26.text:
network’s event calendar and it's our platform
for new research, curatorial and interpretation

33.text:
projects and innovations in museum-based learning
programmes relating to portraits and portrait

39.text:
collections.
It encompasses a wider array of activities

44.text:
in the network. So for example, the UBP, the
Understanding British Portraits network aims

50.text:
to provide expertise sharing, networking and
other opportunities for those with a professional

55.text:
engagement with British portraits. And today’s
event is complimented by a range of collection

60.text:
visits and seminars through the year, Fellowships,
an array of online resources. So it's a very

66.text:
active and lively network.
In terms of participation, I hope all of you

72.text:
will engage today and we would be delighted
if you would share your thoughts on the seminar

76.text:
and the activities of the network. The network
tailors its activities to the needs of the

83.text:
sector. So let us know how we can help you
develop your research, interpretation and

86.text:
learning around your own collection of portraits.
And you can do this via the evaluation form

92.text:
which you have apparently in your delegate
folder, you can Tweet today and the address

98.text:
is apparently displayed on screen. There it
is, lower left, or via our website or email.

104.text:
So do let us know your thoughts.
Just a few words about Fellowships too. We

109.text:
recently launched our new Fellowship programme
which assists museum professionals to develop

114.text:
their own research and learning projects.
The fellowships are an enhanced version of

119.text:
our bursary programme under which almost 40
museum and gallery professionals were able

125.text:
to develop their portrait expertise and deliver
projects to benefit their collections. So

130.text:
three Fellowships are open for applications
at the moment which we will allow the recipients

135.text:
to work on their own portrait-focused projects
next year. All information is in your delegate

140.text:
folder and application forms are on the website
and the deadline is Monday the thirtieth of

146.text:
November, so not far off now.
Just to give you some sense about our upcoming

151.text:
events. We have the Woburn Abbey study day
in December and this has proved extremely

157.text:
popular and is unfortunately now at capacity
but we’re going to be making a short film

162.text:
on the day which will be online in the New
Year, so you can join in to that visit if

167.text:
you were unable to actually attend and to
visit Woburn Abbey itself.

172.text:
We have a workshop at Bethlehem’s Royal
Hospital’s Museum of the Mind which reopened

176.text:
this spring after a very impressive upgrade.
This event is devised by one of the network

181.text:
bursary recipients, Caroline Smith, Education
and Outreach Officer at the Museum of the

187.text:
Mind. Its focus will be Henry Hering’s small
series of photographic patients portraits

193.text:
- or portraits of patients - of the late 1850s
which is a curious group which considers this

198.text:
history of medical illustration, photography
as a diagnostic tool, and phrenology. You

204.text:
can read more about this event and the speakers
in the delegate folders. Finally, next spring

209.text:
there’ll be a study day with our network
partner, the National Trust and Hardwick Hall

214.text:
in Derbyshire, to explore its fantastic collection
of portraits and again, more news will follow

219.text:
in the newsletter.
Just a few thanks for today’s events. I

224.text:
want to thank all of today’s speakers and
to the many of you who responded to the call

229.text:
for papers and to share your current work
and successful case studies and your research

235.text:
findings. We hope that you’ll consider taking
part in next year’s Annual Seminar when

240.text:
we invite proposals next year. We also want
to thank the Arts Council England for its

244.text:
support of the network and activities such
as this. Finally I want to welcome and to

249.text:
thank today’s two co-chairs. So the morning
chair, Jennifer Scott, Director of the The

255.text:
Holburne Museum in Bath. And the afternoon
chair is Ian Dejardin, Director of Dulwich

259.text:
Picture Gallery, both of which we have a very
good relationship with as people and institutions.

264.text:
So on that note, I'm going to hand over to
Jennifer. Jennifer, thank you. Thank you all.
